article.title: Poisonous Plants
article.desc: Some of the following plants can be toxic to your dog. Check with your veterinarian before having them in your home.

article.title: Why do I need to keep my pet from antifreeze?
article.desc: Antifreeze makes your car run better in the summertime and wintertime, but it’s dangerous to your pet.

article.title: Could the pesticides and fertilizers I use on my lawn be dangerous to my pet?
article.desc: If you plan to use pesticides or fertilizers on your lawn, be mindful of your cat or dog.

article.title: Dental Care
article.desc: If possible, get your puppy accustomed to having his teeth cleaned on a regular basis at home.

article.title: Can dogs get dental crowns?
article.desc: The process of crowning damaged teeth is common in human dentistry.

article.title: Should I really brush my dog's teeth?
article.desc: A dog’s dental health depends a lot on its breed and diet. But dogs can get gum disease from plaque on their teeth.

article.title: What is a Phantom Pregnancy?
article.desc: If your female dog is acting like she’s expecting, don’t necessarily anticipate new pups.

article.title: What are the first signs of pregnancy in a dog?
article.desc: If you suspect that your dog is pregnant, the best way to find out for sure is to take her to the veterinarian.

article.title: My dog is going to have puppies. What happens during a normal delivery?
article.desc: If your dog’s expecting, here’s what you should expect on the big day. Within twenty-four hours of giving birth, your dog will likely become very restless and may reject food.

article.title: Basic Commands
article.desc: When using the "come" command, the owner should first call the dog by name followed by "come".

article.title: Housetraining
article.desc: Unless you can catch him in the act, it really does not do any good to your dog to drag him off to the site of his mishap and try and punish him.

article.title: Preventative Training
article.desc: Preventive training means you try to prevent your dog from exhibiting inappropriate behavior by keeping an eye on him when he is with you, or by keeping him in his crate or a puppy/dog-proofed area when you cannot keep an eye on him.

article.title: 4 Key Tips to Successful Crate Training
article.desc: Crate training is not putting your dog/puppy in a "cage" or "jail", and you are not being cruel if you follow these tips.

article.title: What is the theory behind clicker training?
article.desc: Training animals by using a clicking device was developed by psychologist B.F. Skinner more than fifty years ago.

article.title: How can I keep my dog from pulling on the leash so much?
article.desc: If your dog is pulling on its leash, experts say both you and fido have developed a very bad habit.

article.title: My dog is misbehaving. Who might I ask for help?
article.desc: If you adopt a puppy, you might enroll her in a training class to learn basic commands.

article.title: Why is it important for me to be able to handle my dog's food and take treats away from him? How can I safely teach my dog to let me do this?
article.desc: Make no bones about it! Food is precious to a dog, so his instinct is to guard it.

article.title: What is the best behavior advice for new puppy owners?
article.desc: To raise a well-behaved puppy, first, take the time to learn the developmental stages in a young dog's life - like the difference between imprinting and socialization.

article.title: What behavioral training should I give my adolescent dog?
article.desc: Of all the life stages in the career of a well-behaved dog, adolescence can be the most trying.

article.title: What should I consider when purchasing a new dog leash?
article.desc: The best leash allows you to communicate with your dog and keep him under control.

article.title: Exercising with your Dog
article.desc: Exercising with your dog not only strengthens the bond you two share, it also helps control his weight and maintain a healthy heart, lungs and muscles.

article.title: Exercising with your Dog Checklist
article.desc: Keeping your dog fit through exercise helps them lead happier, healthier lives. Here are a few tips to get you started:

article.title: Maintaining a Healthy Weight
article.desc: Dog owners can take several different steps to help control their dog’s weight.

article.title: Understanding your Dog's Body Condition
article.desc: Ribs, lumbar vertebrae, pelvic bones and all bony prominences evident from a distance. No discernible body fat. Obvious loss of muscle mass.

article.title: Why does my dog suddenly have a pot belly?
article.desc: If your pet suddenly has a pot belly, it’s no laughing matter. A distended abdomen can be dangerous.

article.title: How do I know how much exercise my pet can handle after surgery?
article.desc: After your pet has had an operation, you may wonder how quickly he can resume his normal exercise routine.

article.title: How can I help my dog lose weight?
article.desc: So you finally have your obese dog on that weight-loss diet. You're going to prolong his life and restore his health.

article.title: How will a physical therapist work with my dog after surgery?
article.desc: If you ever had orthopedic surgery - maybe for your knee or your shoulder - you know the importance of post-operative physical therapy.

article.title: What are some possible causes of weight loss in dogs?
article.desc: Is your canine losing weight, almost like he's counting calories? If so, you'll need to take him to the veterinarian.

article.title: Emergency First Aid Tips
article.desc: In an emergency, keep a level head and quickly get your dog to the veterinarian. Call first.

article.title: What happens if an un-vaccinated dog is bitten by a rabid animal?
article.desc: You may have seen a wild animal with rabies acting erratically, like a raccoon, out in the middle of the day.

article.title: How do I know if my dog has heatstroke?
article.desc: Bright sun. Hot day. No shade. These factors can spell trouble for your furry friend. If your dog looks dazed or can’t get up, he may have heat stroke.
